lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with properties, we can go further with conditional rendering to make the component as flexible as possible.

Rendering JSX based on certain conditions is called conditional rendering.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can move the conditional statement inside the embedded expression.

Use the conditional statement shorthand to display prize only if it's not undefined.

Make sure to pick prize !== undefined, followed by ?, and finally :.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can shorten this by using the AND operator to render the prize variable only if the condition on the left side evaluates as true.

Check if prize is not undefined to decide whether to render the prize variable.

Make sure to pick prize !== undefined, followed by &&, and finally prize.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We don't have to render a variable that references JSX. We can directly render JSX, too.

Make sure to pick <p>, followed by You won a prize!, and finally </p>.

lessons.title: b
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use the logical OR operator. This operator will first try to render the left side.

If the left side evaluates as falsy, which are false-like values, it will render the right side.

Make sure to pick prize, followed by ||.

lessons.title: b - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If the left side is false, null, undefined, 0, NaN, or an empty string, the OR operator will return the right side to be rendered.

Set the initial value to an empty string instead of undefined.

Make sure to pick "".

lessons.title: b - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can go one step further and only put the variable inside an embedded expression.

If the variable is not falsy, React will render it.

Make sure to pick {, followed by prize, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a conditional rendering that displays a message only if the user has a ticket.

Make sure to pick hasTicket, followed by &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will the following code display if the passed property hasBonus is false?

Your bonus: Your bonus: Extra Vacation!Your bonus: falseNo bonus available

Your bonus: .

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the OR operator to provide a default message when a surprise is not available.

Make sure to pick surprise, followed by ||.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What message does this code display initially?

Gift: Gift unavailableGift: GiftGift: trueGift: null

Gift: Gift unavailable.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a conditional rendering for a user's access level. Display Admin Panel only if the user has an admin role.

Make sure to type &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Consider the following code. What would the displayed outcome be?

Discount: No discount availableDiscount: nullDiscount: Discount: true

Discount: No discount available.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: A common use case for conditional rendering is to display parts of the elements based on a user action or the result of a calculation.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we use the AND operator, we can also pass a multi-line JSX snippet with one parent and multiple child elements.

Wrap the two paragraphs inside a div element to show it when the showMore variable is true.

Make sure to pick showMore followed by && and then <div>, </div>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use as many embedded expressions for conditional rendering as we want.

Use a negation operator in front of the showMore variable to show three dots if the text is hidden to indicate that there is more to read.

Make sure to pick { followed by !showMore and then &&, }.

lessons.title: s
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can add a third embedded expression that returns different text for the button based on how much we are rendering.

Make sure to pick showMore, followed by ?, and finally :.

lessons.title: s - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Or hide the button entirely after it is clicked once. The possibilities with embedded expressions and conditional rendering are endless.

This is a bit of a brain-twister. If showMore is not true, we show the button. As soon as it is true, we hide it.

Make sure to pick !showMore, followed by &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the conditional rendering technique to display a message when fans are cheering.

Make sure to pick cheer, followed by &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will the following React app display when the button is clicked?

The treasure is hidden under the old oak treeThe secret is forever hiddenButton text changes to Hide SecretNothing is displayed

The treasure is hidden under the old oak tree.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use conditional rendering to show or hide the message based on the weather and change the button's label based on the state variable.

Make sure to pick rainy followed by ? and then :, rainy, &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when the following button is clicked twice?

The light is off and the button shows Turn the light onThe light is on and the button shows Turn the light offThe light stays on with no message changeThe button will read Power Off

The light is off and the button shows Turn the light on.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement conditional rendering to display information based on the character's selection.

Make sure to pick character followed by === and then "Hero", &&.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is displayed in this component when the button is clicked?

Here are the detailed stats of our performanceDetailed performance stats are hiddenDetails remain unchanged but button text changesAn error is displayed

Here are the detailed stats of our performance.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Sometimes, we want to show a radically different UI based on a condition.

Think about a loading state. A loading state might be much, much simpler than the view with all the data loaded and presented.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use conditional rendering to display those two states inside an embedded expression.

Based on the loading variable, display either a simple loading message or a complex UI with the loaded data.

Make sure to pick { followed by loading and then ?, :, }.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Returning early is a common pattern for conditional rendering based on specific states, such as loading, error, or authentication state.

Check if loading is equal to true. If that's the case, return a simple loading message early.

Make sure to pick if, followed by loading, and finally return.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use multiple early returns to handle several scenarios in a single component.

First, check if the data is still loading, then check if an error occurred, and finally, return the data.

Make sure to pick if (loading) followed by return and then if (error), return, return.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another common use case is authentication.

Add a conditional statement to check if the passed property authenticated is false. If that's the case, return a prompt to log in.

Make sure to pick if followed by ! and then props, ., authenticated, return.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which part of the given JSX code represents a conditional rendering?

if (!isLoggedIn) { return (...); }<h1>Welcome back!</h1>const [isLoggedIn, setIsLoggedIn] = useState(false)<div><h1>Welcome back!</h1></div>

if (!isLoggedIn) { return (...); }.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use an early return statement to show a warning message if the character is not a wizard.

Make sure to pick character followed by !== and then "wizard", return.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
What output would the following code produce on the page when the loggedIn state is false?

Please log inDashboardError rendering the page

Please log in.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create an early return that shows a No available flight message when there are no available flights.

Make sure to pick if followed by availableFlights.length and then === 0, return.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Identify which scenario might require an early return pattern in React.

Displaying a logout message if the user session is expiredRendering the footer of a webpageAdding two numbersStyling a button with CSS

Displaying a logout message if the user session is expired.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use conditional rendering to show either a Join Us button or Welcome, member text.

Make sure to pick if followed by ! and then isMember, return, return.
